Crl.M.C.No.6072 of 2019
Dated this the 6" day of January, 2020
ORDER

The petitioners are the first and the second accused in the
case registered as O.R.No.3/2019 of the Mankulam Forest Range
Office.

2. The offences alleged against the petitioners are under
Sections 27(1)(a), 27(1)(e)(i) and 27(1)(e)(iv) of the Kerala
Forest Act, 1961.

3. The prosecution case is as follows: On 26.06.2019,
when the Section Forest Officer conducted inspection of the Kallar
Section of the reserve forest with forest officials, he found the
bamboo and the undergrowth there being cut and destroyed from
an area of half acres of forest. Then they heard sound from the
nearby place and when they reached there, they saw accused 3

2020/KER/81
Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 3
to 7 cutting and destroying the bamboo and the undergrowth
there. The statements of the aforesaid persons revealed that
they were employed by the first and the second accused to do
the work.

4. This petition is filed under Section 482 Cr.P.C for
quashing the proceedings against the petitioners in the case
registered as O.R.No.3/2019 in relation to the aforesaid incident.

5. Heard learned counsel for the petitioners and the
learned Public Prosecutor.

6. The plea of the petitioners is as follows: The
petitioners are in absolute possession of 2 Acres and 47 cents of
land in Mankulam Village. The aforesaid land has been in their
absolute possession since the year 1995. They had cultivated
the aforesaid land with black pepper, arecanut, coconut trees,
mango trees etc. There are also two houses situated in the
aforesaid land. The petitioners, along with some other persons,
had filed W.P.(C) No.14674/2007 before this Court claiming
benefit of the Kerala Land Reforms (Amendment) Act, 2005 and
the Kerala Stay of Eviction Proceedings Act, 2005 seeking a

2020/KER/81

Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 1
declaration that they are eligible and entitled to get certificates of
title to the property mentioned above. The aforesaid writ petition
was disposed of by this Court as per Annexure-3 judgment by
directing the petitioners to raise their claims before the
concerned authority. It was also ordered that status quo as on
the date of judgment shall continue. The petitioners have filed
application before the Forest Settlement Officer, Mankulam and
the Revenue Divisional Officer, Devikulam for getting certificates
of title in respect of their land. When the revenue authorities
came to the property of the petitioners, the officials of Mankulam
Forest Range did not permit them to survey the said property.
The Revenue Divisional Officer had informed the petitioners to
clear the bushes and shrubs for conducting survey. The
petitioners engaged their workers for clearing the grass, bushes
and shrubs. The workers so engaged by the petitioners are
implicated in the case registered by the forest officials. The
petitioners have not committed any offence alleged against them.

7. Learned counsel for the petitioners has contended that
Annexure-3 judgment of this Court would show that the

2020/KER/81
Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 5
petitioners are in possession of the land in question and that it is
not a forest area. Learned counsel for the petitioners would also
invite the attention of this Court to the direction made by this
Court in Annexure-3 judgment that status quo shall continue in
relation to the land.

8. It is true that there is a direction in Annexure-3
judgment that the petitioners can approach the concerned
authority raising their claim and then the concerned authority
shall adjudicate the claim and pass orders and until such time,
status quo as on the date of the judgment will continue.
However, it is to be noted that, the direction in Annexure-3
judgment that status quo will continue, is applicable to the
petitioners also.

9. It is admitted in the petition that the petitioners had
employed accused 3 to 7 in the case to clear the grass, shrubs
and bushes in the disputed land. However, there is a specific
recital in the spot mahazar prepared by the Section Forest Officer
that the workers of the petitioners had cut the bamboo in the
disputed land. Learned counsel for the petitioners would submit

2020/KER/81
Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 ,
that they have not cut any bamboo from the land in question.
However, in a petition filed under Section 482 Cr.P.C, this Court
cannot decide such disputed facts.

10. The offences alleged against the petitioners are under
Sections 27(1) (a), 27(1)(e)(i) and 27(1)(e)(iv) of the Kerala
Forest Act. Section 27(1) (a) of the Act prescribes the
punishment for committing any act prohibited by Section 7 of the
Act. Section 7 of the Act provides that, during the interval
between the publication of the notification under Section 4 and
the date fixed by the notification under Section 19, no right shall
be acquired in or over the land included in such notification under
Section 4 except under a grant or contract in writing made or
entered into by, or on behalf of, the Government, or by, or on
behalf of, some person in whom such right, or power to create
the same was vested when the notification under Section 4 was
published, or by succession from such person; and no clearings
shall be made on such land, nor shall any person cut, collect, or
remove any forest produce not shall set fire to such land or
kindle or leave burning any fire in such manner as to endanger

2020/KER/81
Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 ;
the same. In the instant case, admittedly, there is a notification
issued by the government under Section 4 of the Act on
16.05.2007 in respect of the land in dispute proposing to
constitute it as reserve forest.

11. Section 27(1)(e)(i) of the Act presrbies the punishment
for a person, who, in a Reserved Forest or in a land proposed to
be constituted a Reserved Forest cultivates or clears or breaks up
any land for cultivation or for any other purpose or puts up any
shed or other structures or plant trees. Section 27(1)(e)(iv) of
the Act presrbies the punishment for a person, who trespasses
upon such land.

12. It is evident from the aforesaid provisions that
commission of any prohibited act even in a land proposed to be
declared as a reserved forest would attract the offences
mentioned above.

13. Prima facie, there are materials to show that the
petitioners had cut and destroyed the bamboo as well as the
undergrowth from the disputed land. Whether the disputed land
is forest area declared as a reserve forest or proposed to be

2020/KER/81
Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019 ;
declared as a reserved forest and whether it is a land in the
actual possession of the petitioners or not and whether the
petitioners have got any right to be in possession of such land
etc. are matters which cannot be considered and decided in this
petition filed under Section 482 Cr.P.C.

14. It is well settled that, in a petition filed under Section
482 Cr.P.C for quashing preliminary report of charge, this Court
shall not embark upon the validity and reliability of the evidence
available. Factual disputes cannot be decided in a petition filed
under Section 482 CrP.C. All that the Court shall examine is
whether there are allegations in the first information report or
the complaint which form the basis to constitute the ingredients
of the offences alleged against the accused.

15. In the instant case, prima facie, the occurrence report
and the mahazar prepared by the forest officers reveal the
necessary basic ingredients of the offences alleged against the
petitioners. Therefore, the prayer in the petition for quashing the
proceedings against the petitioners cannot be allowed. The
petition is liable to be dismissed.

Feel

2020/KER/81

Cr1.M.C.No.6072/2019
9
Consequently, the petition is dismissed.

R.NARAYANA PISHARADI, JUDGE
